causes: Harsh German colonial policies, including forced labor for cotton plantations
Heavy taxation and economic exploitation of indigenous communities
Cultural and religious opposition to German rule
Widespread belief in the mystical power of 'Maji' (sacred water), which was thought to make warriors immune to bullets
events_leading_up_to_war: Introduction of forced labor policies in 1902
Kinjikitile Ngwale, a spiritual leader, claimed to have divine powers and called for rebellion
First attacks on German outposts in July 1905

result.general: German military victory, brutal suppression of the rebellion
result.treaty: No formal treaty; rebellion was violently crushed
result.territorial_changes: German East Africa remained under German colonial rule

allies: Some local tribes allied with the Germans

entities: Various ethnic groups including Ngoni, Matumbi, and Yao warriors

Maji_Maji_Rebels.weapons: Spears, bows, poisoned arrows, some firearms

Maji_Maji_Rebels.civilian_losses: Mass executions, destruction of villages, famine caused by German scorched-earth tactics

major_battles.name: Attack on Mahenge
major_battles.description: Maji Maji warriors attacked German garrisons but were repelled due to superior German firepower.

major_battles.name: Battle of Kilwa
major_battles.description: German forces launched a counteroffensive, burning villages and executing suspected rebels.

major_battles.name: Final Suppression Campaign
major_battles.description: Germans systematically destroyed rebel villages, crops, and food supplies, leading to widespread starvation.

terms: Mass killings and executions of suspected rebels
Use of scorched-earth policies to destroy food sources
Forced deportations and imprisonment of surviving rebels
impact: German rule remained harsh but later included minor reforms
Strengthened African resistance movements against colonialism

long_term_effects: Increased anti-German sentiment in East Africa
Inspired future independence movements in Tanzania
German colonial brutality exposed to international scrutiny
Weakened German ability to control its colonies leading up to World War I

economic: Severe economic collapse in the region due to mass deaths
political: Led to harsher colonial policies by Germany
Considered one of the first large-scale African uprisings against European rule
social: Cultural loss due to the destruction of villages and traditional governance
